title: Grace Snyder
text:
Grace Bell McCance Snyder (April 23, 1882 – December 8, 1982), is an American <a href="quilter">quilter</a>, former <a href="settler">pioneer</a> and <a href="centenarian">centenarian</a>, whose story is known through the books "No Time on My Hands" and "Pioneer Girl: Growing Up on the Prairie".
Biography.
Childhood.
Grace McCance went to <a href="Nebraska">Nebraska</a> with her parents in 1885 to homestead in a <a href="sod%20house">sod house</a> in <a href="Custer%20County%2C%20Nebraska">Custer County</a>. She had nine siblings. As a small child, she pieced <a href="Quilt%20block">quilt blocks</a> while tending the family's cows.
Adulthood.
McCance married Bert Snyder in 1903 and lived on a ranch forty miles (70 km) northwest of <a href="North%20Platte">North Platte</a>,<ref name="QNM Mar/832"></ref> where they raised four children: <a href="Nellie%20Snyder%20Yost">Nellie Snyder Yost</a>, Miles, Billie, and Bertie.
The relatively isolated ranch life gave McCance ample time for <a href="quilting">quilting</a>, and she became nationally recognized for the skill and complexity of her <a href="Quilt">quilts</a>. The <a href="Congress%20of%20Quilters">Congress of Quilters</a> Hall of Fame in <a href="Arlington%2C%20Virginia">Arlington, Virginia</a>, inducted her in 1980, as did the <a href="Nebraska%20Quilters">Nebraska Quilters</a> Hall of Fame in 1986.
McCance lived to be 100 years old. She is buried in North Platte Cemetery in <a href="North%20Platte%2C%20Nebraska">North Platte, Nebraska</a>.
Books.
McCance is remembered by her own memoir "No Time On My Hands" as told to her daughter Nellie Snyder Yost. 
Her story is also told in the children's biography "" by <a href="Andrea%20Warren">Andrea Warren</a> (Morrow Junior Books, 1998).
